name: (2E)-3-(4-Chlorophenyl)-1-(4-methoxyphenyl)-2-propen-1-one
Reason: The target compound has a base unit of benzene, which has a melting point of about 5.5°C. The presence of the 4-chlorophenyl group is expected to significantly increase the melting point, possibly by around +40°C, due to its electron-withdrawing nature and the induction of intermolecular dipole-dipole interactions. The 4-methoxyphenyl group also raises the melting point, due to additional dipole-dipole interactions by the methoxy group, estimated at around +30°C. The carbonyl group (C=O) in the propenone structure is a polar functional group which can increase the melting point by around +50°C because of its capacity for strong dipole-dipole interactions and potential hydrogen bonding. Lastly, the conjugation in the alkenone (propenone) backbone typically increases molecular rigidity, which can contribute an additional +10°C to the melting point. Summing these individual contributions: 5.5 (benzene base) + 40 (chlorophenyl) + 30 (methoxyphenyl) + 50 (carbonyl) + 10 (conjugation) gives a predicted total increase.
Test (Predicted reason):

This effect can be estimated at around 40 degrees Celsius. The presence of a methoxyphenyl group, which is a phenyl group with an oxygen atom attached, also increases the melting point due to the additional mass and the possibility of hydrogen bonding with the oxygen.
